comment.body: 纸飞机不能用了的话即使留着客户端也没有什么效果呀。有条件的话可能还是各自写私有协议比较好。不起眼就不会被针对了。
@霸王寨第一光头: 这边似乎并没有异常。ZeroMe还在1.5k，你的站点有200。
@霸王寨第一光头: 没有用前置代理和洋葱的话，也有被内网了的可能。用了的话，可能是hidden service坏掉了也说不定。
@紙上掃雷: Actually ES2017 has await. You have to use stuff like Babel for now but it is there.
ZeroNet的文档对于这个问题也没有说清楚……自己试着写评论的时候也是几乎完全照搬ZeroBlog的做法，不知所以然。ZeroNet建一个新站很容易，而维持一个大容量站点却比较难，想要全都放在一个地址下面的理由是什么呢？
是的。这件事是ZeroNet的UI Server插入的iframe外面的代码处理的。
@霸王寨第一光头: 独立的站点当然不能不经用户同意随意添加。如果有Merger权限的话，可以用[这个API (clearnet)](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#mergersiteadd-addresses)。
这个名为Plasmmer的用户，在ZeroNet上名为Peeper，近一段时间一直在发表有关“自己被监视”的言论，还将nofish也卷入阴谋论。不能排除被迫害妄想症的可能性( ´∀｀)
@猫叉酱（小号）: 放轻松啦。仔细读这个人的文章的话就会发现他说的话很奇怪，况且他写的ZeroMe复制站哪里有被“指控他的人”监听控制的意义呢？有可能是Beholder玩多了吧ε-(´∀｀*)
@猫叉酱（小号）: 西方国家又没有禁止洋葱。真的像他说的一样，自己的IP被监控的话，用Tor换个IP不就可以正常发布了。恐怕到时候要说整个Tor网络都是针对他的阴谋了。
不是在GitHub上有源码嘛。
@霸王寨第一光头: 这样的状况的话只能加油解读了(´・ω・｀)
……那么想做第一话痨吗(/_;)
向复制出来的UI上添加功能应该是可以的吧。
因为cert_signers里面没有列出匿名证书的签发者，所以签名的文件不会被其他节点接受，自然就看不到了。想要传递的话建立一个接受匿名证书的Hub，然后想办法让其他人做种就可以了。
@霸王寨第一光头: 修改merged类型就可以了。不过Merger的意义本来就在于将不同来源的信息综合到一个环境上，不想看的话不去添加特定Hub就可以。一定要完全隔离开似乎有些没有必要(´-﹏-`；)
@Bigbigbig: 这取决于你加入的Hub。至少在KaffieHub是可以用的。如果是只接受ZeroID的Hub的话就会像你说的那样。
会喜欢匿名的人之间也是不一样的。不是只有需要奇怪的资源这样一种理由啦。
@霸王寨第一光头: 用WebSocket API运行查询应该会方便一些。ZeroNet的动态页面都是在本地生成的，所以一定要用分析HTML的办法的话，反而会变得很麻烦吧(｡>﹏<｡)
需要批量签名文件的话可以考虑建立一个有ZeroMe的Merger权限的站点，这样就可以调用API自动化更换过程了。
@Zefinity: 麻烦才需要自动化嘛(´-﹏-`；)如果不改其他Hub的data.json的话，应该会使得在那些Hub留下的评论仍然链接到旧Hub。
@Zefinity: 自己这边看Nests的链接，没有出现这样的情况。
@Zefinity: 嗯，确实是这样……ZeroMe涉及多个Hub时总是产生混乱，不太清楚情况。
两边都错开一点不好吗(@_@)
可以用UDP广播包实现本地发现。
@霸王寨第一光头: 不清楚(´･_･`)印象中Syncthing在本地局域网中就是这样发现客户端的。
@霸王寨第一光头: 感觉本地网络大概不会用到IPv6吧(@_@)
@霸王寨第一光头: IPv6的话可以用多播地址吧，大概。
@霸王寨第一光头: 咦……竟然延迟了这么久吗∑(ﾟДﾟ)
@霸王寨第一光头: 确实是个问题。目前的ZeroHello的可扩张性不是特别好。
@ulrichard: No. Gallery stubs are prefixed by their source sites' addresses (or domains if they have any), and will not collide globally. You only need to ensure uniqueness within your own hub.

@ZAlex: Are you having a really narrow window that hits `min-width`, then? In that case it would still be fixed by going responsive.

@ulrichard: Currently, you will have to use the filter feature. I'm planning to add a 'group by tag' feature which was originally intended for manga, but should fit your use case as well. I don't have a timeline for that, though. It's just one of my fun projects, after all.
@Musickiller: Thanks for the appreciation! To be honest, though, I never cared too much about being "big". Nevertheless, it's still fun for me, at least for now, so there is no need to worry.

@Musickiller: Oh, so you mean scrolling *vertically*. Didn't think about that as it's the expected behavior for book pages, but I see how it can be problematic for standalone images. For a proper fixed footer I'll have to switch to full flexbox, so it will take some time. For now you can add something along the lines of `max-height: 80vh` using userstyle if you don't like the width fit.

@Binchan: You are welcome desu. In fact I should thank you for the ideas.

> Pick an average PC from 2007 and install a minimal Linux based operating system. You will be able to do basic computing tasks

Doubt this is going to work too well for phones. PC was standardized so that all devices work up to a lowest common denominator, even if one does not have the software needed to utilize them properly. Phones are not designed with this interoperability in mind, so support will always be a case-by-case matter.

@Binchan: Running Linux on a chroot kind of defeats the purpose, as you are still running the vendor's Android beneath, and it can basically do anything to your Linux. Problem is, hardware vendors likely won't want to cooperate with the community to bring working drivers. Their customers are phone vendors, not end users, and phone vendors want their bloatware/adware/spyware to stay. The community alone won't be able to do much: just watch the train wreck that is nouveau. On PC you can still use your fancy graphics card as a VGA chip like it's from 80's. No universal standards like that for phones.

There are several reasons why I use `const` when possible. Future proofing for better performance, so that it can run faster when browsers finally support ES6, *is* one of them, but it is not the most important.

My main objective of using `const` is constraining myself, so that I have less room to make mistakes without the compiler complaining. Mutable states are not only hard for compilers. They are hard for us as well. So I intend to avoid them when possible. It's the same line of reasoning behind the old `use strict`, which does not make much runtime difference, if at all.

It is also my personal belief, that source code are written for humans, not machines. Even without a runtime effect, a mere semantic difference can convey information to human readers of the code. In this case, `const` makes it clear that a symbol is not meant to be bound to another value. It may be the one thing that the following code deals with, or just a humble single use intermediate for simplifying expressions, but certainly not something that is going to change. And I consider this to be useful.
Will consider if I have the time to figure it out.
Looks more like classic Mac OS, considering window decoration and menu bar.
I hope there will be a time when seeing Linux desktops on mainstream media is no longer surprising.
@Binchan: I... totally kept that in mind. Totally. The code is a bit messy and in need of refactoring but I think it would be ready by this weekend. Or not. But maybe.
And there are more waiting in the later chapters.

[@Binchan:](?Profile/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/binchan2@zeroid.bit "mention:1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h") It looks nice. I guess we can all use a high-contrast scheme from time to time. 

> colors can look very different between an IPS screen and a LED one

Colors can look very different between *every pair of uncalibrated screens in existence*. All screens and desktops should have had color management, and instead we got this mess. sRGB was a mistake.
[@Binchan:](?Profile/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/binchan2@zeroid.bit "mention:1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h") Too flashy for me I guess...

[@Binchan:](?Profile/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/binchan2@zeroid.bit "mention:1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h") I'm not sure if there is a clean way to do what you have described, but if you think you can somehow manage, then sure, have a try at it. Honestly I would prefer something less complex than that.

[@Binchan:](?Profile/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/binchan2@zeroid.bit "mention:1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h") If you check the color codes in `silvery.less` you will find out that the backgrounds are not even a single bit red. This is apparently an issue with your monitor calibration (or lack thereof).

That's something that I unfortunately cannot possibly understand, as I have no idea about your conception of "clean" or "dirty" colors. They seem fine to me. What I can say for sure, is that they are not red, and if you see any red, you should do what the highest voted answer of the question you linked suggested: get a colorimeter.

You should also keep in mind that a lot of monitors lack uniformity, which means the same color code get shown differently at different places on the panel. You can easily check that by getting your monitor to show a full screen of #FFFFFF. Some monitors come with a factory-calibrated "uniformity compensation" option, but if there is none, there is nothing I can do about that, either.

Anyway, it should be easy enough to add a palette to `|><||>`, and with the upcoming settings UI, it should be easy enough to switch between palettes as well. Your palette could be added to the repository if you wish so.

[@Binchan:](?Profile/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/binchan2@zeroid.bit "mention:1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h")

[@Binchan:](?Profile/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/binchan2@zeroid.bit "mention:1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h") Sounds fine! Please go ahead if you would like to implement it.

[@Binchan:](?Profile/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/binchan2@zeroid.bit "mention:1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h") Looks pretty hacky though. Not sure if this is the direction a default layout should go. If I'm to implement this I would embed a `post-list` in the user panel, on the markup level, instead. I don't really like it when one superimpose two elements and pretend that it was one. You may do whatever you see fit however, that's what userstyles are for, after all!

I don't care whether you follow me or not.

[@Binchan:](?Profile/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/binchan2@zeroid.bit "mention:1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h") Autohide is fine. Now that I'm reminded of that big 0 button by your screenshot, I'm starting to think that it might be better on the bottom instead. Not sure about hiding headers, they look like pretty important info to me, at least, but perhaps I just have a poor working memory.
[@Binchan:](?Profile/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/binchan2@zeroid.bit "mention:1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h") Fine then.

[@Binchan:](?Profile/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/binchan2@zeroid.bit "mention:1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h") Maybe. If it works for you.
